column10: Bio_ID

column9: The woman who challenged Yājñavalkya on the nature of Brahman
column10: In the royal court of Janaka, Gārgī twice interrogates Yājñavalkya on the ultimate substratum of reality, pushing him to reveal Brahman as the imperishable thread weaving all existence. Declared unequalled among knowers of Brahman, she exemplifies the brahmavādinī tradition of female philosophers in ancient India.
column11: यत् तत् अप्राकृतं गार्गि तत् अक्षरं गार्ग्य अक्षरं ब्रह्म
column12: “That which is above the heavens and below the earth… on what is that woven, warp and woof?”
column15: Pahāṛī painting of female sage in debate

column9: She who chose knowledge of the Self over wealth
column10: When Yājñavalkya prepares to renounce the world, Maitreyī asks: “If this whole earth filled with wealth were mine, would I become immortal?” Receiving the answer “No”, she demands the teaching that grants immortality — the famous neti-neti doctrine of the Ātman.
column11: न वा अरे पत्युः कामाय पतिः प्रियो भवति, आत्मनस्तु कामाय पतिः प्रियो भवति
column12: “Not for the sake of the husband is the husband dear, but for the sake of the Self.”
column15: Kangra miniature of couple in forest hermitage

column9: Ṛṣikā who composed the dialogue hymn on love and dharma
column10: Created by sages from the finest parts of animals, Lopāmudrā persuades her ascetic husband Agastya to fulfil conjugal duties while preserving spiritual pursuit — Ṛgveda 1.179 remains a rare erotic-spiritual dialogue by a female seer.
column12: Desire roars in the heart like a lion.

column9: Overcame illness through her hymns to Ashvins
column10: Granddaughter of Dīrghatamas, afflicted by a skin disease, she composes two hymns that win the grace of the Ashvins and restore her health and marriage.
column11: अपां नपात् पुनर् आ पुनर् आ वि शते
column12: May the Ashvins restore me again and again.

column9: Cured of skin disease by Indra
column10: Apālā offers soma to Indra through her mouth; the god cures her and she composes a hymn of gratitude.
column15: Vedic scene with woman pressing soma

column10: Her hymn 5.28 invokes Agni for marital harmony and prosperity.
column11: अग्ने वः पत्या रत्या वि भव
column12: May Agni make you two united in love.

column9: Female seer of a hymn to Indra
column10: One of the few women seers listed in Vedic indices, her hymn praises Indra's strength.

column9: Seer of a hymn on cosmic order
column10: Her verse in Ṛgveda 10.154 invokes the river goddess for protection and fertility.

column9: Composer of a hymn to Varuṇa
column10: Her hymn seeks Varuṇa's grace for moral order and prosperity.

column9: First ordained woman, founder of nuns' order
column10: The Buddha's foster mother and aunt, she led 500 women to ordination, establishing the bhikkhunī saṅgha despite initial reluctance.

column9: Foremost in wisdom, queen turned arahant
column10: King Bimbisāra's chief queen, she realized no-self through the Buddha's teaching on form's impermanence.
Lotus-hued beauty who used iddhi to multiply herself, later renouncing to teach Dhamma.

column9: Foremost in Vinaya knowledge, led 500 nuns
column10: After losing family in tragedy, she mastered precepts and guided grieving women to enlightenment.
Ex-nun who taught her husband the five aggregates, praised by Buddha as his equal.
Defeated Sāriputta in debate, then ordained; foremost in quick wit.
To Māra's question "Who are you?", she replied: a mere process, no being.
Princess who rejected kingship for nunhood, composing verses on dependent origination.
King Sahasrānīka's daughter, renounced throne for omniscience through rigorous tapas.

column9: Sister-in-law of Neminātha, led mass renunciation
column10: Inspired by Neminātha's asceticism, she and 14,000 women took dikṣā.
One of three women authorities cited in Mahābhāṣya for rare Sanskrit forms.
Cited alongside Śikhatā for grammatical precision in Patañjali's commentary.
Her example on compound words preserved in Nyāsa commentary.
Cited by Pāṇini commentators for a unique grammatical usage.
7th-c. debater who won public arguments against Buddhist logicians.
Her fragments in anthologies showcase subtle alaṃkāra and emotion.
Quoted for elegant verses on love and nature in Sāhityadarpaṇa.

column9: Verse quoted in Daṇḍin's mirror of poetry
column10: Her line exemplifies śleṣa (double meaning) in Kāvyādarśa.
Her stanzas on devotion and beauty preserved in medieval collections.
Fragments in vachana style prefiguring Akka Mahādevī.

column9: Transformed into pey to worship Śiva's dance
column10: Abandoned beauty for skeletal form, composing hymns at Tiruvalangadu temple.
Promoted Shaivism in court, featured in Periyapurāṇam.
Her hymns in Tevaram praise Śiva temples.

column9: Only female Āḻvār, wed Viṣṇu mystically
column10: Composed Tiruppāvai for Margaḻi festival, merging with Ranganātha idol.
Feigned madness to escape marriage, realized non-duality in charnel ground.
With Kanakhalā, practiced tantra in forests, attaining siddhis.
Mastered illusory body practices, among 84 mahāsiddhas.

column9: Founder of Shangpa Kagyu, Nāropa's consort
column10: Taught six yogas, emphasizing dream yoga and clear light.
Sister of Lakṣmīṅkarā, initiated in guhyamantra rites.
Consolidated Kashmir throne, patronized Shaiva rites.

column9: Daughter of physician, quoted in Suśruta
column10: Authority on pediatric dosages in ancient surgery text.
Cited for infant care in Kāśyapa Saṃhitā.

column9: Naked wanderer devoted to Chenna Mallikārjuna
column10: Rejected husband and clothes, sang 350+ vachanas on divine love.
Her vachanas emphasize equality and Śiva devotion.
Verses on linga as inner self in Lingayat canon.

column9: Mystic whose vakhs blend Shaiva and Sufi
column10: Wandered naked, composing 138 quatrains on non-dual consciousness.

column9: Wife of Hemādpant, composed abhaṅgas on Viṭhobā
column10: Early bhakti voice in Marathi, but dates ~1270s.
Rejected palace for songs of divine love, but death post-1500—include as emergent.
column11: पायो जी मैंने राम रतन धन पायो
column12: I found the jewel of Ram.
